bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 5, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison advises Hench on his speech and describes the conferring of the honorary degree.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, October 5, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
October 5, 1940

div1.p:
I sent you a telegram last night indicating
that we had better not try the slides at this dinner
but that we would like to take your main photographs
and print them in the program for the dinner so that
the people who have them not only can see while you
talk but take with them for permanent keeping. The
difficulty of using slides at a dinner of this kind
is that it involves moving the people around in the
midst of the dinner, changing their chairs, moving
them down from the balcony, and various other compli-
cations. Anything which causes people to move from
their dinner table after a dinner breaks the psychology
of the evening. This is an axiom for dinner speaking,
and your effort will be twice as great for the same
result if we do that. The finest group to speak to
is that group which you catch fresh after the dinner,
in their places, ready for the address and responsive,
and it will be much easier for you. Our experience
is such that we are very much afraid of pictures at a
dinner of this kind.

On the other hand, we do believe that we can
get up a program which will be a souvenir which will
contain the program of the evening and the menu and
carry these pictures of the “Yellow Jack” experiment.
We will work this out as soon as your pictures arrive.

You do not speak at any other occasion during
the week-end so you need not worry about that.

The conferring of the degree is very simple.
You simply stand in the place which I will indicate to you,
at my right on the platform, facing toward me rather than
the audience. When I hand you the diploma, in the course
of the citation, you take it with your left hand and
remove your hat with your right hand so that the hood may
be put over your head. After that, you replace the hat
and we shake hands. I do not kiss you!

Buddy Groves arrived in America with his
family on September twenty-fourth. He has decided to
accept the position at Centre College, Danville, Kentucky,
as Professor of Bible. He drove through on his way to
that position, night before last, spending the night at
our home. They are now there getting settled. You can
address them at Centre College, Danville. I doubt if he
Doctor P. S. Hench
-2-
October 5, 1940
can be up here for Founders' Day and of course I would
rather not have him then so far as I am concerned
because I will be too busy. However, I wouldn't be very
busy on the following day, Sunday. We have nothing
special then. I am hoping you folks can stay over
so that we can have a visit. If Buddy could come up then
I would be delighted to have him here. We will send him
an invitation just to see what happens and you can drop
him a note.
div1.closer:
Affectionately yours, Hutch Doctor P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
RCH/M
P.S. We too originally planned for the
use of your slides, but that was when
we were putting your talk in between
the acts on the night of the play.
Now that we have shifted you to the
major occasion, the dinner, we think
the slides won't work as they would
have worked on the play night. I
forgot to make this note in writing
the above.
R.C.H.
